Risk Description:
An attacker exploits insecure designs or lack of adoption of security controls (e.g. hardening) in O-RAN components causing:
 - Loss of service
 - Privacy issues
 - Performance issues in the system in O-RAN components
Impact Description: Unauthenticated/unauthorized access of the O_RAN component leads to compromised performance and/or function/service, lateral attack towards other O-RAN system component(s) from inside, and loss/stolen/tampering of sensitive data
Applied factors:
• Exposure (High): A1, O1, E2, xApps, rApps
 • Adverse impacts (High)
Rationale:
O-Cloud security hardening requirements have not been specified yet and it is unclear whether the industry practices sufficiently cover the threats outlined.
 
 O-RAN Alliance has specified security for O-RAN interfaces at the transport layers thereby mitigating access to O-RAN functions through the interfaces. The O-RAN Alliance has not yet specified security for protecting the platforms that host the O-RAN functions from physical or remote access.

Risk Description:
An attacker exploits misconfigured or poorly configured O-RAN components causing:
 - Loss of service
 - Privacy issues
 - Performance issues in the system
Impact Description: Unauthenticated/unauthorized access of the O_RAN component leads to compromised performance and/or function/service, lateral attack towards other O-RAN system component(s) from inside, and loss/stolen/tampering of sensitive data
Rationale: O-Cloud security hardening requirements have not been specified yet and it is unclear whether the industry practices sufficiently cover the threats outlined.

Risk Description:
Attacks from the internet exploit weak authentication and access control to penetrate O-RAN network boundary, causing:
 - Flooding of the network - loss of service, performance issues
 - Unauthorized access to ORAN components
Impact Description:
Denial of service for component access and/or function/service offered;
 Unauthenticated/unauthorized access of the O_RAN component leads to compromised performance and/or function/service, lateral attack towards other O-RAN system component(s) from inside, and loss/stolen/tampering of sensitive data;
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any xApp security measures around the Onboarding onto SMO and deployment onto Near RT-RIC, authentication and access control, secure configuration, etc. Further, there is no testing framework in place for xApps yet. This attack to be performed requires multiple steps to be achieved by an attacker.
Considered Assumptions: The O-RAN network elements should not be exposed to untrusted/ internet end points without network access control.

Risk Description:
An attacker attempts to flooding the airlink signal (legitimate communications) through IoT devices causing:
 - Loss of service
Impact Description: Denial of service for component access and/or function/service offered
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any security measures on flooding attacks through IoT devices.

Risk Description: An attacker penetrates and compromises the O-RAN system through the open O-RAN’s Fronthaul, O1, O2, A1, and E2
Rationale: Existing controls are in place (moderately satisfactory), Malicious user needs to have direct (physical) access to the target system

Risk Description: An attacker exploits insufficient/improper mechanisms for authentication and authorization to compromise O-RAN components
Impact Description: Unauthenticated/unauthorized access of the O_RAN component leads to compromised performance and/or function/service, lateral attack towards other O-RAN system component(s) from inside, and loss/stolen/tampering of sensitive data
Rationale: Existing controls are in place (moderately satisfactory), Attack can be launched from the internet or untrusted network
Considered Assumptions: Authentication procedures are in place

Risk Description: An attacker compromises O-RAN monitoring mechanisms and log files integrity and availability
Impact Description: Compromise of availability and integrity of security event log files could conduct to delays, wrong audit results, delays in security restoration, threats persistence.
Rationale: Existing controls are in place (moderately satisfactory), Malicious user needs to have administrative or elevated privileges in the target system. It is a likely scenario after initial compromise of network elements.
Considered Assumptions: Authentication procedures , patch management regular programmed update, vulnerability handling/regular scanning, SBOM are in place

Risk Description: An attacker compromises O-RAN data integrity, confidentiality and traceability
Impact Description: An attacker could, in such case, data tampering, information disclosure, spoofing identity, elevation of privilege, etc.
Rationale: Existing controls are in place (moderately satisfactory). Likely scenario after initial compromise of network elements with local data storage.
Considered Assumptions: Protection at rest (e.g. HSM) is in place (operator decision),

Risk Description: An attacker compromises O-RAN components integrity and availability
Impact Description: An attacker could, in such case, cause denial-of-service, data tampering, information disclosure, spoofing identity, etc.
Rationale: Existing controls are in place (moderately satisfactory), Malicious user needs to have direct access to the target system

Risk Description:
A successful attack could:
 -compromise confidentiality, integrity and availability due to the prolonged undetected presence of an attacker in the network
Impact Description: confidentiality, integrity, availability
Applied factors:
• Impact on confidentiality, integrity and availability (High)
 • Threat event initiation (High)
Rationale:
- Impact on confidentiality, integrity, and availability (High): fragmented logs lead to undetected breaches, tampering, and delayed responses, causing significant data loss, integrity issues, and system disruptions.
 - Threat event initiation (High): Adversary behaviour generally goes undiscovered.

Risk Description: An attacker penetrates O-DU and beyond through O-RU (bidding-down attack)
Impact Description: Data tampering and information disclosure;
Applied factors:
• Threat event initiation (Medium)
 • Adverse impacts (Medium)
 • Exposure (Medium)
Rationale: System has an amount of exposed interfaces: multiple O-DU, multiple O-RU, FH interface. It is a possible attack, however needs physical access and sophistication to execute

Risk Description: An attacker penetrates O-DU and beyond through O-RU (bidding-down attack)
Impact Description: Spoofing
Applied factors:
• Threat event initiation (Medium)
 • Adverse impacts (Medium)
 • Exposure (Medium)
Rationale: System has an amount of exposed interfaces: multiple O-DU, multiple O-RU, FH interface. It is a possible attack, however needs physical access and sophistication to execute

Risk Description: Unauthorized access to the Open Front Haul Ethernet L1 physical layer interface (cables and connections)
Impact Description: It provides a means to launch attacks on the confidentiality of the Open Front Haul system.
Rationale: It is a possible attack, however needs physical access and sophistication to execute

Risk Description: Unauthorized access to the Open Front Haul Ethernet L1 physical layer interface (cables and connections)
Impact Description: It provides a means to launch attacks on the availability of the Open Front Haul system.
Rationale: It is a possible attack, however needs physical access and sophistication to execute

Risk Description: An attacker attempts to intercept the Fronthaul (MITM) over M Plane to obtain protected information
Impact Description: Passive wiretapping
Rationale: It is a possible attack, however needs physical access and sophistication to execute
Considered Assumptions: TLS with PKI is supported, it is up to MNO, the likelihood is low provided that MNOs use TLS over the M-Plane

Risk Description: An attacker attempts to intercept the Fronthaul (MITM) over M Plane to alter m-plane data
Impact Description: Intercepting and modifying of the M plane messages.
Rationale: It is a possible attack, however needs physical access and sophistication to execute
Considered Assumptions: TLS with PKI is supported, it is up to MNO, the likelihood is low provided that MNOs use TLS over the M-Plane

Risk Description: An attacker attempts to intercept the Fronthaul (MITM) over M Plane to disrupt services
Impact Description: Denial of service
Rationale: It is a possible attack, however needs physical access and sophistication to execute
Considered Assumptions: TLS with PKI is supported, it is up to MNO, the likelihood is low provided that MNOs use TLS over the M-Plane

Risk Description: DoS attack on an O-DU acting as master to distribute network timing toward O-RU based on point-to-point connection in LLS-C1. In this scenario, only one O-RU is connected to O-DU, therefore only that O-RU is affected.
Impact Description: This attack may cause performance degradation or interruption of services to only one O-RU that rely on accurate time from the affected O-DU. The severity level is consequently 'Low'.
Rationale: Slightly exposed to external systems: one O-RU. It is a possible attack, however needs physical access and sophistication to execute
Considered Assumptions: Access control on the CUSM-Plane that mitigates unauthorized access by an insider are in place. 802.1x protocol is supported it can reduce the likelihood of this attack.

Risk Description: DoS attack on an O-DU acting as master to distribute network timing toward O-RU based on point-to-point connection in LLS-C1. In this scenario, multiple O-RUs are connected to O-DU, therefore those O-RUs are affected.
Impact Description: This attack may cause performance degradation or interruption of services to all the RUs that rely on accurate time from the affected O-DU. The severity level is consequently 'Medium'.
Rationale: System has a medium amount of exposed interfaces: multiple O-RUs. It is possible attack, however needs physical access and sophistication to execute

Risk Description: DoS attack on an O-DU acting as master to distribute network timing toward O-RU in LLS-C2. One or more Ethernet switches are allowed between the central site (hosting O-DUs) and the remote sites (hosting O-RUs).
Impact Description: This attack may cause performance degradation or interruption of services to all the RUs that rely on accurate time from the affected O-DU. In this configuration, a neighbor O-DU could act a backup and play the role of a master to distribute network timing to all the RUs belonging to the affected O-DU by reconfiguring the network of switches. The severity level is consequently 'Low'.
Rationale: System has a medium amount of exposed interfaces. It is a possible attack, however needs physical access and sophistication to execute
Considered Assumptions: Access control on the CUSM-Plane that mitigates unauthorized access by an insider are in place. 802.1x protocol is supported it can reduce the likelihood of this attack.

Risk Description: DoS attack against a Master clock in the LLS-C3 configuration
Impact Description: In this configuration, the frequency and timing distribution is made by the fronthaul network (not by O-DU). DoS attack against a master clock may cause performance degradation or interruption of services to all the RUs and DUs that rely on accurate time from the affected master clock in the fronthaul network. The severity level is consequently 'High'.
Rationale: System has a medium amount of exposed interfaces. It is a possible attack, however needs physical access and sophistication to execute

Risk Description: DoS attack against a Master clock in the LLS-C4 configuration
Impact Description: In this configuration, the time source could be locally embedded in the RU itself. DoS attack in the time source may cause performance degradation or interruption of services to only one O-RU where the time source is embedded. The severity level is consequently 'Low'.
Rationale: Slightly exposed to external systems: one O-RU. It is a possible attack, however needs physical access and sophistication to execute
Considered Assumptions: Access control on the CUSM-Plane that mitigates unauthorized access by an insider are in place. 802.1x protocol is supported it can reduce the likelihood of this attack.

Risk Description: Impersonation of a Master clock (Spoofing) within a PTP network with a fake ANNOUNCE messages
Impact Description:
Degradation in the accuracy of time may cause DoS to applications on all the RUs that rely on accurate time, potentially bringing down the cell.
 A cell outage caused by misaligned time, may further impact performance in connected neighboring cells.
Rationale: Existing controls are in place to prevent, or at least significantly impede, the vulnerability from being exercised. It is a possible attack, however needs physical access and sophistication to execute
Considered Assumptions: Access control on the CUSM-Plane that mitigates unauthorized access by an insider are in place. 802.1x protocol is supported it can reduce the likelihood of this attack.

Risk Description: A Rogue PTP Instance wanting to be a Grand Master by sending manipulated/malicious ANNOUNCE messages declaring him to be the best clock in the network
Impact Description:
Degradation in the accuracy of time may cause DoS to applications on all the RUs that rely on accurate time, potentially bringing down the cell.
 A cell outage caused by misaligned time, may further impact performance in connected neighboring cells.
Rationale: Existing controls are in place to prevent, or at least significantly impede, the vulnerability from being exercised. It is a possible attack, however needs physical access and sophistication to execute
Considered Assumptions: Access control on the CUSM-Plane that mitigates unauthorized access by an insider are in place. 802.1x protocol is supported it can reduce the likelihood of this attack.

Risk Description: Selective interception and removal of PTP timing packets
Impact Description:
Clock degradation in attacked nodes. Removing all packets or random packets may push the clocks in attacked nodes into free running mode.
 Degradation in the accuracy of time may cause DoS to applications on all the RUs that rely on accurate time, potentially bringing down the cell.
 A cell outage caused by misaligned time, may further impact performance in connected neighboring cells.
Rationale: Existing controls are in place to prevent, or at least significantly impede, the vulnerability from being exercised. It is a possible attack, however needs physical access and sophistication to execute
Considered Assumptions: Access control on the CUSM-Plane that mitigates unauthorized access by an insider are in place. 802.1x protocol is supported it can reduce the likelihood of this attack.

Risk Description: Packet delay manipulation attack
Impact Description:
Degradation in the accuracy of time may cause DoS to applications on all the RUs that rely on accurate time, potentially bringing down the cell.
 A cell outage caused by misaligned time, may further impact performance in connected neighboring cells.
Rationale: Existing controls are in place to prevent (moderately satisfactory). It is a possible attack, however needs physical access and sophistication to execute
Considered Assumptions: 802.1x protocol is supported it can reduce the likelihood of this attack.

Risk Description: Spoofing of DL C-plane messages
Impact Description:
The lack of authentication could allow an adversary to inject own DL C-plane messages that falsely claiming to be from the associated O-DU. 
 As a result, it would block the O-RU to process the corresponding U-Plane packets, leading to temporarily DoS. (dropping the entire DL C-plane messages would achieve same goal)
Rationale: Existing controls are in place to prevent, or at least significantly impede, the vulnerability from being exercised. It is a possible attack, however needs physical access and sophistication to execute
Considered Assumptions: 802.1x at the ethernet level ensures authentication and authorization for communication over FH interface, not sure that this control reduce the risk of spoofing of c-plane at a low level. Mitigations related to monitoring and configuration of network nodes are in place

Risk Description: Spoofing of UL C-plane messages
Impact Description:
The lack of authentication could allow an adversary to inject own UL C-plane messages that falsely claiming to be from the associated O-DU.
 As a result, temporarily limited cell performance (or even DoS) on cells served by the O-RU and in addition a consequential threat to all O-RUs parented to that O-DU might exist. (dropping the entire UL C-plane messages would achieve same goal)
Rationale: Existing controls are in place to prevent, or at least significantly impede, the vulnerability from being exercised. It is a possible attack, however, needs physical access and sophistication to execute
Considered Assumptions: 802.1x at the ethernet level ensures authentication and authorization for communication over FH interface, not sure that this control reduce the risk of spoofing of c-plane at a low level. Mitigations related to monitoring and configuration of network nodes are in place

Risk Description: An attacker attempts to intercept the Fronthaul (MITM) over U Plane to obtain user data (PDCP protocol is used)
Impact Description: For the transported U-Plane data an attacker could potentially do threats, such as passive wiretapping, but would need to break PDCP Security prior to any content access.
Rationale: Existing controls are in place to prevent, or at least significantly impede, the vulnerability from being exercised. It is a possible attack, however, needs physical access and sophistication to execute
Considered Assumptions: 802.1x protocol is supported it can reduce the likelihood of this attack.

Risk Description: An attacker attempts to intercept the Fronthaul (MITM) over U Plane to modify u-plane data (PDCP protocol is used)
Impact Description: For the transported U-Plane data an attacker could potentially do threats, such as passive wiretapping, but would need to break PDCP Security prior to any content access.
Rationale: Existing controls are in place to prevent, or at least significantly impede, the vulnerability from being exercised. It is a possible attack, however, needs physical access and sophistication to execute
Considered Assumptions: 802.1x protocol is supported it can reduce the likelihood of this attack.

Risk Description: An attacker attempts to intercept the Fronthaul (MITM) over U Plane to disrupt services (PDCP protocol is used)
Impact Description: For the transported U-Plane data an attacker could potentially do threats, such as passive wiretapping, but would need to break PDCP Security prior to any content access.
Rationale: Existing controls are in place to prevent, or at least significantly impede, the vulnerability from being exercised. It is a possible attack, however, needs physical access and sophistication to execute
Considered Assumptions: 802.1x protocol is supported it can reduce the likelihood of this attack.

Risk Description: Spoofing and unauthorized access of U-Plane data packets
Impact Description: An attacker could degrade service quality, disrupt legitimate data flow, and potentially cause a DoS.
Rationale: Existing controls are in place to prevent, or at least significantly impede, the vulnerability from being exercised. It is a possible attack, however, needs physical access and sophistication to execute
Considered Assumptions: 802.1x protocol is supported it can reduce the likelihood of this attack.

Risk Description: An attacker stands up a rogue O-RU (standalone) - a false base station
Impact Description: This opens the door to subscriber’s identity interception/disclosure and unauthorized user tracking attacks (privacy breach).
Rationale: Existing controls are in place to prevent (moderately satisfactory). It is a possible attack, however needs physical access and sophistication to execute
Considered Assumptions: Security measures already defined by 3GPP, monitoring/detection mechanisms of a rogue ORU are in place

Risk Description: An attacker stands up a rogue O-RU attacking O-DU and beyond (core network)
Impact Description: It provides a means to launch attacks on the availability, integrity, and confidentiality of the Open Front Haul system, ODUs and beyond in the core network.
Rationale: Existing controls are in place to prevent, or at least significantly impede, the vulnerability from being exercised. It is a possible attack, however needs physical access and sophistication to execute
Considered Assumptions: 802.1x protocol is supported it can reduce the likelihood of this attack.

Risk Description: Malicious xApps can exploit UE identification, track UE location and change UE priority
Impact Description:
An xApp can receive order via A1 to control a certain UE and if a malfunctioning xApp receives an order to prioritize this UE, then the owner of the malfunctioning xApp knows a VIP that they want to track in a certain area. With this command exposure, the attacker can obtain a rough location of a very important person and change the order from prioritize to deprioritize for a UE;
 Interception of UE identifier
Applied factors:
• Threat event initiation (High)
 • Adverse impacts (High)
 • Exposure (High)
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any xApp security measures around the Onboarding onto SMO and deployment onto Near RT-RIC. Further, there is no testing framework in place for xApps yet.

Risk Description: Risk of a malicious xApp on Near-RT RIC to obtain protected information
Impact Description: Deployment of malicious xApps may allow unauthorized access to E2 Nodes, abuse of radio network information, or exploit UE identification and location.
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any xApp security measures around the Onboarding onto SMO and deployment onto Near RT-RIC. Further, there is no testing framework in place for xApps yet.

Risk Description: Risk of a malicious xApp on Near-RT RIC impacting service availability
Impact Description: Deployment of malicious xApps may allow impacting service or exploit slice priority.
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any xApp security measures around the Onboarding onto SMO and deployment onto Near RT-RIC. Further, there is no testing framework in place for xApps yet.

Risk Description: Near-RT RIC APIs can be compromised and manipulated due to lack, incorrect or weak authentication mechanism
Impact Description: Near-RT RIC data around services and UEs can be eavesdropped.
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any Near-RT RIC APIs measures.

Risk Description: Near-RT RIC APIs can be compromised and manipulated due to lack, incorrect or weak authentication mechanism
Impact Description: Unauthenticated APIs can be manipulated causing services disruptions in RAN network
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any Near-RT RIC APIs measures.

Risk Description: Resources and services provided by Near-RT RIC platform and xApps via APIs can be abused and/or misused
Impact Description: Near-RT RIC data around services and UEs can be eavesdropped by xApps without proper permissions.
Applied factors:
• Threat event initiation (High)
 • Adverse impacts (High)
 • Exposure (High)
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any Near-RT RIC APIs measures.

Risk Description: Resources and services provided by Near-RT RIC platform and xApps via APIs can be abused and/or misused
Impact Description: Abuse of resources and misuse of services can produce disruptions and/or outages in the network.
Applied factors:
• Threat event initiation (High)
 • Adverse impacts (High)
 • Exposure (High)
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any Near-RT RIC APIs measures.

Risk Description: Risk of deployment of a malicious, non-uniquely identified xApps using a trusted xAppID to access resources and services which they are not entitled to use.
Impact Description: theft of services, data leakage
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any xApp security measures around the xAppID yet.

Risk Description: An attacker gains access to the Non-RT RIC through the SMO to cause a denial of service or degrade the performance of the Non-RT-RIC
Impact Description:
Non-RT RIC would not be able to:
 •monitor or trace the network to understand the effect of policy on performance in Near-RT RIC 
 •update A1 policy •provide exposure and secure delivery of A1 Enrichment Information to Near-RT RIC •setup access control rules and the selection of which Enrichment Information ID (EiId) is exposed to a near-RT RIC
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any security measures around the authentication and access control to the Non RT-RIC.

Risk Description: An attacker gains access to the Non-RT RIC through the SMO for UE tracking
Impact Description: Attacker has access to sensitive data and is able to track a UE
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any security measures around the authentication and access control to the Non RT-RIC.

Risk Description: An attacker gains access to the Non-RT RIC through the SMO to cause Data Corruption/Modification
Impact Description: A malicious actor who gains unauthorized access to the Non-RT-RIC can modify policy to pass a “False Policy” to the Near-RT-RIC to degrade performance or cause an outage.
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any security measures around the authentication and access control to the Non RT-RIC.

Risk Description: An attacker exploits xApps vulnerabilities and misconfiguration to alter data transmitted over A1 or E2 interfaces.
Impact Description:
If attackers can find exploitable xApp, they can disrupt the offered network service and potentially take over another xApp or the whole Near-RT RIC. 
 The actual consequences may vary. For example, an attacker may gain the ability to alter data transmitted over A1 or E2 interfaces, extract sensitive information, etc.
Applied factors:
• Threat event initiation (High)
 • Adverse impacts (High)
 • Exposure (High)
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any xApp security measures around the Onboarding onto SMO and deployment onto Near RT-RIC, authentication and access control, secure configuration, etc. Further, there is no testing framework in place for xApps yet.

Risk Description: An attacker exploits xApps vulnerabilities and misconfiguration to extract sensitive information.
Impact Description:
If attackers can find exploitable xApp, they can disrupt the offered network service and potentially take over another xApp or the whole Near-RT RIC. 
 The actual consequences may vary. For example, an attacker may gain the ability to alter data transmitted over A1 or E2 interfaces, extract sensitive information, etc.
Applied factors:
• Threat event initiation (High)
 • Adverse impacts (High)
 • Exposure (High)
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any xApp security measures around the Onboarding onto SMO and deployment onto Near RT-RIC, authentication and access control, secure configuration, etc. Further, there is no testing framework in place for xApps yet.

Risk Description: An attacker exploits xApps vulnerabilities and misconfiguration to disrupt Near-RT RIC functions
Impact Description:
If attackers can find exploitable xApp, they can disrupt the offered network service and potentially take over another xApp or the whole Near-RT RIC. 
 The actual consequences may vary. For example, an attacker may gain the ability to alter data transmitted over A1 or E2 interfaces, extract sensitive information, etc.
Applied factors:
• Threat event initiation (High)
 • Adverse impacts (High)
 • Exposure (High)
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any xApp security measures around the Onboarding onto SMO and deployment onto Near RT-RIC, authentication and access control, secure configuration, etc. Further, there is no testing framework in place for xApps yet.

Risk Description: An attacker exploits xApps vulnerabilities and misconfiguration to gain unauthorized control over Near-RT RIC
Impact Description:
If attackers can find exploitable xApp, they can disrupt the offered network service and potentially take over another xApp or the whole Near-RT RIC. 
 The actual consequences may vary. For example, an attacker may gain the ability to alter data transmitted over A1 or E2 interfaces, extract sensitive information, etc.
Applied factors:
• Threat event initiation (High)
 • Adverse impacts (High)
 • Exposure (High)
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any xApp security measures around the Onboarding onto SMO and deployment onto Near RT-RIC, authentication and access control, secure configuration, etc. Further, there is no testing framework in place for xApps yet.

Risk Description: Conflicting xApps impact O-RAN system functions to degrade performance or trigger a DoS
Impact Description: An attacker can utilize a malicious xApp that intentionally triggers RRM decisions conflicting with the O-gNB internal decisions to create denial of service or performance degradation.
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any xApp security measures around the Onboarding onto SMO and deployment onto Near RT-RIC, authentication and access control, secure configuration, etc. Further, there is no testing framework in place for xApps yet.

Risk Description: An attacker compromises xApp isolation
Impact Description: Gaining unauthorized access to the underlying system provides new opportunities to exploit vulnerabilities in other xApps or O-RAN components to intercept and spoof network traffic, to degrade services (DoS), etc.
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any xApp security measures around the Onboarding onto SMO and deployment onto Near RT-RIC, authentication and access control, secure configuration, etc. Further, there is no testing framework in place for xApps yet.

Risk Description: False or malicious A1 policies modify behavior of xApps
Impact Description: A malicious A1 policy can exploit xApp functionality to trigger a DoS, affect performance, or locate a subscriber.
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any xApp security measures around the Onboarding onto SMO and deployment onto Near RT-RIC, authentication and access control, secure configuration, etc. Further, there is no testing framework in place for xApps yet. This attack to be performed requires multiple steps to be achieved by an attacker.

Risk Description: Conflicting rApps impact O-RAN system functions to degrade performance or trigger a DoS
Impact Description: rApps in the Non-RT RIC performing different functions can be provided by different vendors. This creates the risk that different rApps will take conflicting decisions to set conflicting policies. This can result in performance degradation or outage.
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any rApp security measures around the Onboarding onto SMO and deployment onto Non RT-RIC, authentication and access control, secure configuration, etc. Further, there is no testing framework in place for rApps yet.

Risk Description: An attacker exploits rApp vulnerability for data breach or denial of service
Impact Description: Vulnerabilities can potentially exist in any rApp. If attackers can find exploitable rApp, they can disrupt the offered network service and potentially take over another rApp or the non-RT RIC. The consequences may vary. For example, an attacker may gain the ability to alter data transmitted over A1 interface, extract sensitive information, etc.
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any rApp security measures around the Onboarding onto SMO and deployment onto Non RT-RIC, authentication and access control, secure configuration, etc. Further, there is no testing framework in place for rApps yet.

Risk Description: An attacker exploits rApps misconfiguration
Impact Description: Security misconfiguration, such as open ports or enabled unused protocols, can potentially exist in an rApp. If attackers can find exploitable rApp, they can disrupt the offered network service and potentially take over another rApp or the whole non-RT RIC. The actual consequences may vary. For example, an attacker may gain the ability to alter data transmitted over A1 interface, extract sensitive information, etc.
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any rApp security measures around the Onboarding onto SMO and deployment onto Non RT-RIC, authentication and access control, secure configuration, etc. Further, there is no testing framework in place for rApps yet.

Risk Description: An attacker bypasses authentication and authorization
Impact Description: An Attacker can exploit an rApp that has weak or misconfigured authentication and authorization to gain access to the rApp and pose as a tenant.
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any rApp security measures around the Onboarding onto SMO and deployment onto Non RT-RIC, authentication and access control, secure configuration, etc. Further, there is no testing framework in place for rApps yet.

Risk Description: An attacker deploys and exploits malicious rApp
Impact Description: An untrusted source may intentionally provide a malicious rApp. A trusted source may have a backdoor intentionally inserted in the rApp. If attackers can find exploitable rApp, they can disrupt the offered network service and potentially take over another rApp or the whole Non-RT RIC. Malicious rApps could impact Non-RT RIC functions such as AI/ML model training, A1 policy management, Enrichment information management, Network Configuration Optimization in the purpose of performance degradation, DoS,
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any rApp security measures around the Onboarding onto SMO and deployment onto Non RT-RIC, authentication and access control, secure configuration, etc. Further, there is no testing framework in place for rApps yet.

Risk Description: An attacker bypasses authentication and authorization using an injection attack
Impact Description: It is possible that an attacker to submit requests without prior authentication and authorization by executing an injection attack to manipulate configurations, access logs, perform remote code execution, etc.
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any rApp security measures around the Onboarding onto SMO and deployment onto Non RT-RIC, authentication and access control, secure configuration, etc. Further, there is no testing framework in place for rApps yet.

Risk Description: rApp exploits services
Impact Description: A malicious rApp or a trusted but compromised rApp can exploit services such as O1 services across the R1 interface
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any rApp security measures around the Onboarding onto SMO and deployment onto Non RT-RIC, authentication and access control, secure configuration, etc. Further, there is no testing framework in place for rApps yet.

Risk Description: An attacker compromises a PNF to launch attacks against VNFs/CNFs
Impact Description:
Data tampering and information disclosure;
 
 Unauthenticated/unauthorized access of the O_RAN component leads to compromised performance and/or function/service, lateral attack towards other O-RAN system component(s) from inside, and loss/stolen/tampering of sensitive data;
Rationale: This is a likely attack but may need physical access to the PNF.

Risk Description: An attacker compromises a PNF to launch Denial of Service attacks against VNFs/CNFs
Impact Description: Denial of service from within for component access and/or function/service offered
Rationale: This is a likely attack but may need physical access to the PNF.

Risk Description: An attacker can exploit the misconfigured/poorly implemented authentication mechanism on SMO functions
Impact Description: The data stored in the SMO may be exposed/manipulated to an attacker.
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any SMO security measures around authentication, access control, secure configuration, etc.

Risk Description: An attacker can exploit the misconfigured/poorly implemented authorization on SMO functions
Impact Description: An attacker can be able to perform certain actions, e.g. disclose O-RAN sensitive information or alter O-RAN components.
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any SMO security measures around authentication, access control, secure configuration, etc.

Risk Description: Overload DoS attacks at SMO
Impact Description: Inability to deal with such events affects availability of SMO data and functions.
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any SMO security measures around authentication, access control, secure configuration, etc.

Risk Description: Developers use SW components with known vulnerabilities and untrusted libraries that can be exploited by an attacker through a backdoor attack
Impact Description: Attackers can exploit a vulnerability on the open source code and infects a hypervisor, operating system, VM or container with a malware.
Rationale: Vulnerability handling and patch management are not yet defined by O-RAN Alliance. Several CVE have already been discovered on open source software.

Risk Description: A trusted developer intentionally inserts a backdoor into an open source code O-RAN component.
Impact Description: Unauthenticated/unauthorized access of the O_RAN component leads to compromised performance and/or function/service, lateral attack towards other O-RAN system component(s) from inside, and loss/stolen/tampering of sensitive data;
Rationale: Vulnerability handling and patch management are not yet defined by O-RAN Alliance. Several CVE have already been discovered on open source software.

Risk Description: An intruder into a site gains physical access to O-RAN components to cause damage or access sensitive data
Rationale: O-RAN system has many external interfaces. Different O-Cloud deployment models can be used to implement O-RAN. Several scenarios to implement O-RUs and O-DUs are supported by O-RAN.

Risk Description: An intruder into the exchange over the Fronthaul cable network attempts to gain electronic access to cause damage or access sensitive data
Rationale: O-RAN system has many external interfaces. Different O-Cloud deployment models can be used to implement O-RAN. Several scenarios to implement O-RUs and O-DUs are supported by O-RAN.

Risk Description: Disruption through radio Jamming , Sniffing and Spoofing
Impact Description: Service disruption and information exposure
Rationale: These attacks are common and not specific to O-RAN. They are likely to occur, hence they need more investigation and consideration. Mitigations to reduce these types of attacks should be defined by O-RAN Alliance.

Risk Description: DoS attacks on cognitive radio networks
Impact Description: Service disruption
Rationale: These attacks are common and not specific to O-RAN. They are likely to occur, hence they need more investigation and consideration. Mitigations to reduce these types of attacks should be defined by O-RAN Alliance.

Risk Description: A malicious actor gains unauthorized access to R1 services
Impact Description: “Service management and exposure services Producer” determines whether the Service Producer is authorized to produce the service. An attacker can perform a spoofing attack to gain unauthorized access to R1 services.
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any R1 security measures.

Risk Description: Attacker modifies Service Heartbeat message to cause Denial of Service
Impact Description: Attacker can exploit the Service Heartbeat on the R1 by modifying or inserting heartbeat messages to cause denial of service
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any R1 security measures.

Risk Description: Malicious actor bypasses authentication to Request Data
Impact Description: Attacker can exploit password-based authentication on the R1 to request unauthorized data. Weak password management can easily be exploited. (Certificate-based mutual authentication using TLS and PKI X.509 certificates is recommended).
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any R1 security measures.

Risk Description: Malicious actor bypasses authorization to Discover Data
Impact Description: “Data registration and discovery service producer” determines whether the Data Producer is authorized to produce the data types. An attacker can perform a spoofing attack to discover available data.
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any R1 security measures.

Risk Description: A malicious actor gains unauthorized access to data
Impact Description: An attacker can perform a spoofing attack to exploit the Data request and subscription service for the purpose to gain unauthorized access to data.
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any R1 security measures.

Risk Description: Malicious actor modifies a Data Request
Impact Description: Data Consumers consume the “Data request and subscription service” to request data instances or subscribe to them. An attacker can modify a request to force the consumer to receive a different data set then that intended. Without checks, the received data could be processed, leading to erroneous decisions or triggers.
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any R1 security measures.

Risk Description: Malicious actor snoops Data Delivery to the Data Consumer
Impact Description:
Data delivery messages relate to a particular data request or subscription. The data can be delivered to the Data Consumer in different ways, including:
  • as part of the payload of a data delivery message,
 • as a data stream,
  • from e.g., a REST endpoint, a message bus or object store location.
 An attacker can perform snooping, injection, or modification attacks in the Delivery of Data process.
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any R1 security measures.

Risk Description: Untrusted peering between Non-RT-RIC and Near-RT-RIC
Impact Description: Malicious Non-RT-RIC peers with a Near-RT-RIC over the A1 interface, or a malicious Near-RT-RIC peers with a Non-RT-RIC over the A1 interface, due to weak mutual authentication.
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any A1 security measures.

Risk Description: Malicious function or application monitors messaging across A1 interface
Impact Description: Attacker gains access to A1 messaging for reconnaissance
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any A1 security measures.

Risk Description: Malicious function or application modifies messaging across A1 interface
Impact Description: Internal threat actor can gain access to the messaging across the A1 interface for a MiTM attack to modify or inject policy. This can result in the Near-RT RIC receiving malicious policy.
Rationale: O-RAN Alliance has not specified yet any A1 security measures.

Risk Description: Unauthorized access to Non-RT-RIC- or Near-RT-RIC- resources
Impact Description: A malicious actor can gain access to Near-RT-RIC resources or Non-RT-RIC resources over the A1 interface.
Rationale:
ZTA: ease of performing reconnaissance attacks without immediate detection
  
 Threat event initiation: simple to execute for sophisticated inside actors

Risk Description:
A successful attack could:
 - Compromise the deployed VNF/CNF
Impact Description: Spoofing, Tampering, Information disclosure, Elevation of Privilege
Rationale:
Adverse impacts (Medium) - Only one VNF/CNF might be affected, Existing requirements and controls are defined in the O-RAN specifications that may impede successful exercise of the vulnerability. 
 ZTA (High): Reconnaissance and availability type attacks
Considered Assumptions:
SBOM requirements 
  
 REQ-SEC-SYS-1

Risk Description:
A successful attack could:
 - Deployment of malicious VM/Container (Lack of isolation)
 - Exploit host access to escape the host and reach hardware server then the malicious VM/Container can gain root access to the whole server where it resides
Impact Description: Spoofing, Tampering, Information disclosure, Elevation of Privilege
Rationale:
Adverse impacts (High) - Multiple VNFs/CNFs might be affected
 
 ZTA (High): Reconnaissance and availability type attacks
Considered Assumptions:
SBOM requirements 
  
 REQ-SEC-SYS-1

Risk Description:
A successful attack could:
 - Bypass access controls placed on various resources on O-Cloud
 - Gain increased privilege to specific O-Cloud services
 - Access to restricted areas of the O-Cloud network
Impact Description: Spoofing, Tampering, Information disclosure, Elevation of Privilege
Rationale:
Adverse impacts (Medium) - Requirements are in place for user authentication and authorization
 
 ZTA (High): Reconnaissance type attacks
Considered Assumptions:
REQ-SEC-PASS-1
  
 REQ-SEC-OCLOUD-1
  
 REQ-SEC-OCLOUD-2

Risk Description:
A successful attack could:
 - Make use of a untrusted VM/Container that runs on top of a trusted Hypervisor/Container Engine
Impact Description: Tampering, Information disclosure
Rationale:
Adverse impacts (Medium) - Only one VNF/CNF might be affected
 
 ZTA (High): Reconnaissance type attacks

Risk Description:
A successful attack could:
 - Make use of a trusted VM/Container that runs on top of an untrusted Hypervisor/Container Engine to intercept communication, replace strong or use weak cryptographic keys, etc.
Impact Description: Tampering, Information disclosure
Rationale:
Adverse impacts (High) - Multiple VNFs/CNFs might be affected
 
 ZTA (High): Reconnaissance and availability type attacks

Risk Description:
A successful attack could:
 - Make use of a trusted VM/Container that runs on top of a trusted Hypervisor/Container Engine that runs on top of an untrusted hardware to intercept communication, replace strong or use weak cryptographic keys, etc.
Impact Description: Tampering, Information disclosure
Rationale:
Adverse impacts (High) - Multiple VNFs/CNFs might be affected
 
 ZTA (High): Reconnaissance and availability type attacks

Risk Description:
A successful attack could:
 - Compromise the availability of O-Cloud services
 - Compromise the confidentiality/integrity of O-Cloud services by extracting/modifying critical application data
Impact Description: Information disclosure, Denial of Service
Rationale:
Adverse impacts (High) – No existing controls for interfaces in O-Cloud
 
 ZTA (High): Reconnaissance and availability type attacks

Risk Description:
A successful attack could:
 - view insecurely stored credentials and cryptographic materials
Impact Description: Information disclosure, Elevation of Privilege
Rationale:
Adverse impacts (Medium) – Requirements are defined for sensitive data protection in the O-RAN security specifications
  
 ZTA (High): Reconnaissance type attacks
Considered Assumptions:
REQ-SEC-OCLOUD-SS-1
 REQ-SEC-OCLOUD-SS-2
 REQ-SEC-OCLOUD-SS-3
 SEC-CTL-OCLOUD-SS-1
 SEC-CTL-OCLOUD-SS-2
 SEC-CTL-OCLOUD-SS-3

Risk Description:
A successful attack could:
 - modify insecurely stored credentials and cryptographic materials
Impact Description: Tampering, Elevation of Privilege
Rationale:
Adverse impacts (Medium) – Requirements are defined for sensitive data protection in the O-RAN security specifications
  
 ZTA (Medium): Integrity type attacks
Considered Assumptions:
REQ-SEC-OCLOUD-SS-1
 REQ-SEC-OCLOUD-SS-2
 REQ-SEC-OCLOUD-SS-3
 SEC-CTL-OCLOUD-SS-1
 SEC-CTL-OCLOUD-SS-2
 SEC-CTL-OCLOUD-SS-3

Risk Description:
A successful attack could:
 - Gain access to the sensitive information
 - Escalate privileges in Applications
Impact Description: Information disclosure, Elevation of Privilege
Rationale:
Adverse impacts (Medium) – Requirements are defined for sensitive data protection in the O-RAN security specifications
  
 ZTA (High): Reconnaissance type attacks

Risk Description:
A successful attack could:
 - Compromise VM/Container isolation measures
 - Gain higher privileges on host or any of the containers running on that host
 - Perform unauthorized modifications to the contents of host filesystem e.g. install SSH keys, read secrets mounted to the host, and take other malicious actions
Impact Description: Spoofing, Tampering, Information disclosure, Denial of Service and Elevation of privilege
Rationale:
Adverse impacts (High) – No existing requirements
 
 ZTA (High): Reconnaissance and availability type attacks

Risk Description:
A successful attack could:
 - Deploy a new malicious VM/Container configured without network rules, user limitations, etc. to bypass existing defenses within O-Cloud infrastructure
 - Compromise the confidentiality & integrity of co-hosted VMs/Containers and tenants
 - Launch DDOS attacks on co-hosted VMs/Containers and host services thereby degrading their performance
Impact Description: Spoofing, Tampering, Information disclosure, Denial of Service and Elevation of privilege
Rationale:
Adverse impacts (High) – No existing requirements
 
 ZTA (Medium) - Availability type attacks

Risk Description:
A successful attack could:
 - Retrieve/manipulate VNF/CNF sensitive data (e.g. passwords, private keys, subscription data, logs)
Impact Description: Tampering, Information disclosure
Rationale:
Adverse impacts (High) – No existing requirements
 
 ZTA (High): Reconnaissance type attacks

Risk Description:
A successful attack could:
 - Cause migration Flooding: VM/Container performance degradation and VM/Container crashes
Impact Description: Tampering, Information disclosure, Denial of Service
Rationale:
Adverse impacts (High) – No existing requirements
 
 ZTA (Medium): Availability type attacks

Risk Description:
"A successful attack could:
 - Sniff the packets that are exchanged between the source and destination servers
 - Read the migrated memory pages
 - Monitor and/or modify the received packets while continuing to forward them to victim VM/Container"
Impact Description: Tampering, Information disclosure, Denial of Service
Rationale:
Adverse impacts (High) – No existing requirements
 
 ZTA (High): Reconnaissance type attacks

Risk Description:
A successful attack could:
 - Misguide the Virtualization layer to reduce the resource of or delete a VM/Container on which a VNF/CNF is running. This can result in the reliability, availability or even illegal termination of a VNF/CNF and hence the denial of service
 - Misguide the O-Cloud platform to detach a hardware accelerator from a VNF/CNF
Impact Description: Denial of Service
Rationale:
Adverse impacts (High) – No existing requirements
 
 ZTA (Medium): Availability type attacks

Risk Description:
A successful attack could:
 - Access to data not erased from a terminated VNF/CNF or any VNF/CNF that has released resources
Impact Description: Information disclosure
Rationale:
Adverse impacts (High) – No existing requirements
 
 ZTA (High): Reconnaissance and availability type attacks

Risk Description:
A successful attack could:
 - Insert malicious code that will subsequently get run in the production environment
Impact Description: Tampering, Information disclosure
Rationale:
Adverse impacts (Medium) – Requirements are defined for image protection in the O-RAN security specifications
 
 ZTA (High): Reconnaissance and availability type attacks
Considered Assumptions:
REQ-SEC-ALM-PKG-1 to REQ-SEC-ALM-PKG-15
  
 SEC-CTL-ALM-PKG-1 to SEC-CTL-ALM-PKG-4

Risk Description:
A successful attack could:
 - Intercept network traffic intended for registries and steal developer or administrator credentials within that traffic. Thus, could be used to provide fraudulent or outdated images to orchestrators, etc.
Impact Description: Tampering, Information disclosure
Rationale:
Adverse impacts (Medium) – Requirements are defined for image protection in the O-RAN security specifications
 
 ZTA (High): Reconnaissance and availability type attacks
Considered Assumptions:
REQ-SEC-ALM-PKG-1 to REQ-SEC-ALM-PKG-15
  
 SEC-CTL-ALM-PKG-1 to SEC-CTL-ALM-PKG-4

Risk Description:
A successful attack could:
 - Secrets embedded within a VM/Container image can be stolen 
 - Secrets embedded within a VM/Container image can be modified
Impact Description: Spoofing, Tampering, Information disclosure
Rationale:
Adverse impacts (Medium) – Requirements are defined for image protection in the O-RAN security specifications
 
 ZTA (High): Reconnaissance and availability type attacks
Considered Assumptions:
REQ-SEC-ALM-PKG-1 to REQ-SEC-ALM-PKG-15
  
 SEC-CTL-ALM-PKG-1 to SEC-CTL-ALM-PKG-4

Risk Description:
A successful attack could:
 - Build a custom image on the host that includes malware and then may deploy container using that custom image
Impact Description: Spoofing, Tampering, Information disclosure, Denial of Service and Elevation of privilege
Rationale:
Adverse impacts (Medium) – Requirements are defined for image protection in the O-RAN security specifications
 
 ZTA (High): Reconnaissance and availability type attacks
Considered Assumptions:
REQ-SEC-ALM-PKG-1 to REQ-SEC-ALM-PKG-15
  
 SEC-CTL-ALM-PKG-1 to SEC-CTL-ALM-PKG-4

Risk Description:
A successful attack could:
 - Gain control over the host of a server or install a malicious Hypervisor/Container Engine/Host OS and exploit that to run malicious applications on the VM/Container that run on top of the host. This would enable the attacker to control all the VMs/Containers running on the host.
Impact Description: Spoofing, Tampering, Information disclosure, Denial of Service and Elevation of privilege
Rationale:
Adverse impacts (High) - No existing requirements
 
 ZTA(High) - Reconnaissance and availability type of attacks

Risk Description:
A successful attack could cause:
 - Failure of the physical machine to start at all
 - Physical machine entering a safe-mode
 - Physical machine continuing boot regardless of the integrity measurements
Impact Description: Tampering
Rationale:
Adverse Impact (High) - No existing requirements
 
 ZTA(Medium) - Availability type attacks

Risk Description:
A successful attack could:
 - cause denial-of-service against the service discovery infrastructure to prevent O-Cloud to react to changing resource requirements properly
Impact Description: Denial of Service
Rationale:
Adverse impacts (Medium) – Requirements are defined for O-Cloud authentication and authorization
 in the O-RAN security specifications.
 
 ZTA (Medium): Availability type attacks
Considered Assumptions:
REQ-SEC-OCLOUD-O2dms-1
 REQ-SEC-OCLOUD-O2dms-2
 REQ-SEC-OCLOUD-O2dms-3
 REQ-SEC-OCLOUD-O2dms-4
 REQ-SEC-OCLOUD-O2ims-1
 REQ-SEC-OCLOUD-O2ims-2
 REQ-SEC-OCLOUD-O2ims-3
 REQ-SEC-OCLOUD-O2ims-4
 REQ-SEC-O-CLOUD-NotifAPI-1
 REQ-SEC-O-CLOUD-NotifAPI-2
 SEC-CTL-O-CLOUD-INTERFACE-1
 SEC-CTL-O-CLOUD-INTERFACE-2
 SEC-CTL-O-CLOUD-INTERFACE-3
 REQ-SEC-OCLOUD-ISO-1
 REQ-SEC-OCLOUD-ISO-2
 REQ-SEC-OCLOUD-ISO-3
 REQ-SEC-OCLOUD-ISO-4

Risk Description:
A successful attack could:
 - Tamper/alter/disclose requests and services sent over O2 between O-Cloud and SMO, hence the virtualized resource or relevant status information is not as requested
 - Affect the normal operation of the O-Cloud, and even causes DoS attacks, information leakage.
Impact Description: Tampering, Information disclosure, Denial of Service
Rationale:
Adverse impacts (Low) – Requirements are defined for the protection of O2 interface in the O-RAN security specifications
 
 ZTA (High): Reconnaissance and availability type attacks
Considered Assumptions:
REQ-SEC-O2-1
 SEC-CTL-O2-2
 REQ-SEC-DOS-1

Risk Description:
A successful attack could:
 - Cryptographic keys or other security critical data of an instantiated VNF/CNF could be stolen by an attacker with access to the virtualization layer
 - The virtualized resource provided by the Virtualization layer to the instantiated VNF/CNF can be manipulated
Impact Description: Tampering, Information disclosure, Denial of Service
Rationale:
Adverse impacts (Low) – Requirements are defined for the protection of O-Cloud API in the O-RAN security specifications
 
 ZTA (High): Reconnaissance and availability type attacks
Considered Assumptions:
REQ-SEC-O2-1
 SEC-CTL-O2-2
 REQ-SEC-DOS-1

Risk Description:
A successful attack could:
 - Maliciously placed VM/Container extracts information from the target VM/Container with the side channel attack
Impact Description: Tampering, Information disclosure, Denial of Service
Rationale:
Adverse Impact (High) - No existing requirements
 
 ZTA (High): Reconnaissance and availability type attacks

Risk Description:
A successful attack could:
 - Extract useful information such as cryptographic keys from the target VM/Container to use them for traffic eavesdropping and man-in-the-middle attacks.
Impact Description: Tampering, Information disclosure, Denial of Service
Rationale:
Adverse Impact (High) - No existing requirements
 
 ZTA (High): Reconnaissance and availability type attacks

Risk Description:
A successful attack could:
 - tamper the requests/responses sent between the AAL components, the O-Cloud platform and O-RAN APPs/VNFs/CNFs
Impact Description: Tampering
Rationale:
Adverse impacts (High) – Not security requirements yet for AAL in O-RAN security specifications
 
 ZTA (Medium): Integrity type attacks

Rationale:
Adverse impacts (High) – Not security requirements yet for AAL in O-RAN security specifications
 
 ZTA (Medium): Availability type attacks

Risk Description: In the O-Cloud environment, the reuse of IDs from deleted objects for new objects can lead to unintended data associations, leaks, and operational disruptions.
Impact Description: Tampering, Information disclosure
Rationale:
Adverse impacts (High) – Not security requirements yet for O-Cloud ID in O-RAN security specifications
 
 ZTA (High): reconnaissance and integrity type attacks

Risk Description: In O-Cloud deployments, replacing failed machines without proper management of their corresponding Node objects can lead to resource mismatches, stale data inheritance, and network inconsistencies.
Impact Description: Spoofing, Tampering, Information disclosure, Denial of Service
Rationale:
Adverse impacts (High) – Not security requirements yet for O-Cloud ID in O-RAN security specifications
 
 ZTA (High): reconnaissance, integrity, and availability type attacks

Risk Description: In the O-Cloud environment, improper management of object IDs can lead to overlaps, inconsistencies, unauthorized access, and operational disruptions.
Impact Description: Spoofing, Tampering, Information Disclosure, Repudiation, Elevation of Privilege, Denial of Service
Rationale:
Adverse impacts (High) – Not security requirements yet for O-Cloud ID in O-RAN security specifications
 
 ZTA (High): reconnaissance, integrity, and availability type attacks

Risk Description:
A successful attack could:
 - Lead to the inability to react to changing resource requirements
 - Operators may be unable to retrieve logs, telemetry data
 - Prevents the O-Cloud software update (VNFs/CNFs, VL) to exploit a known security flaw in the O-Cloud software
Impact Description: Denial of Service
Rationale:
Adverse impacts (Medium) – Requirements are defined for the protection against DoS attacks and for the protection of O-Cloud API and O2 interface in the O-RAN security specifications
 
 ZTA (Medium): Availability type attacks
Considered Assumptions: REQ-SEC-DOS-1

Risk Description:
A successful attack could:
 - Deploy new instances and disrupt existing O-Cloud services
 - Submit compromised VM/Container images that unsuspecting tenants then use to initiate O-Cloud services
 - Extract business data, configuration data, user data and possibly credentials
 - Create backups of VM/Container instances or export VM/Container images
Impact Description: Tampering, Information disclosure, Denial of Service and Elevation of privilege
Rationale:
Adverse impacts (Medium) – Requirements are defined for the protection of O-Cloud API and O2 interface in the O-RAN security specifications
 
 ZTA (High): Reconnaissance and availability type attacks
Considered Assumptions:
REQ-SEC-PASS-1
 REQ-SEC-O2-1
 SEC-CTL-O2-2
 REQ-SEC-DOS-1

Risk Description:
A successful attack could:
 - Take alter a subset of the training data by inserting or modifying training samples
Impact Description: Integrity
Applied factors:
• Impact on integrity (High) 
 • Threat event initiation (low)
Rationale:
• Impact on integrity: Bad training data will cause the model to behave incorrectly 
 • Threat event initiation: needs high sophistication to execute

Risk Description:
A successful attack could:
 - generate adversarial examples in the model

Risk Description:
A successful attack could cause :
 - service disruption of the O-RAN elements that are using configuration / policies derived from the manipulated output of a model .
Impact Description: Denial of Service
Rationale:
• Impact on Availability (High): Prolonged interruption of operations.
 • Adverse impacts (Medium) – O-RAN Alliance has specified security for O-RAN interfaces at the transport layers thereby mitigating access to O-RAN functions through the interfaces. The O-RAN Alliance has not yet specified security for regarding the Training or test data sets collected externally or internally, Trained ML model ,
 ML prediction results .

Risk Description: AI/ML models are used to perform QoE optimization and QoE based traffic steering in O-RAN [i.14]. A carefully crafted manipulation of the output of AI/ML model can be used to degrade the QoE of a subscriber or a group of subscribers.
Impact Description: Tampering
Rationale:
• Impact on Integrity (High): Major change in normal AI/ML system functioning.
 • Adverse impacts (Medium) – O-RAN Alliance has specified security for O-RAN interfaces at the transport layers thereby mitigating access to O-RAN functions through the interfaces. The O-RAN Alliance has not yet specified security for regarding the Training or test data sets collected externally or internally, Trained ML model ,
 ML prediction results .

Risk Description: Disruption or manipulation of the time synchronization process within the O-Cloud environment can lead to severe security and operational issues.
Impact Description: An attacker may target the time synchronization mechanisms to alter time settings across nodes, leading to data integrity loss, authentication and authorization bypass, and operational disruption.
Applied factors:
Impact of Integrity and Availability (High)
  
 Threat Event Initiation (Medium)
Rationale:
Impact of Integrity and Availability (High): due to potential widespread operational and security impacts, including data integrity loss and operational disruptions affecting multiple nodes.
  
 Threat Event Initiation (Medium): it requires elevated privileges to modify time synchronization settings.
